comment_text.mn12:1.2: This description of the Buddha’s location is unique.
comment_text.mn12:2.1: Sunakkhatta’s dismal spiritual career began when he met the Buddha in MN 105. In DN 6:5.3 we learn that, after being ordained three years, he spoke of his limited success in meditation. The current sutta and DN 24 deal with Sunakkhatta’s bitter criticisms of the Buddha shortly after his disrobal.
comment_text.mn12:2.3: These distinctions are defined in the Vinaya as “absorption, release, immersion, attainment, knowledge and vision, development of the path, realization of the fruits, giving up the defilements, a mind without hindrances, delighting in an empty dwelling” (Bu Pj 4:3.8). They may be summarized as absorption, psychic abilities, and realization of the paths and fruits.
comment_text.mn12:2.4: The Buddha taught that logic alone is an unreliable guide to the truth (MN 76:27.2, DN 1:1.34.2), a fact of which Sunakkhatta was apparently not aware.
comment_text.mn12:2.5: The Chinese parallel at T 757, rather, raises the question, “How could such a teaching lead to freedom from suffering?”
comment_text.mn12:4.1: “Futile man” (moghapurisa) refers to someone who has been led astray by delusion.
comment_text.mn12:5.1: “Inference from the teaching” (dhammanvaya) is a valid form of knowledge, where someone draws a reasoned conclusion based on fundamental principles (see SN 12.33:7.2).
comment_text.mn12:6.2: The Buddha introduces these here because, as we know from DN 24:1.4.1, Sunakkhatta thought that such displays were a worthy goal of spiritual practice. The Chinese parallel, however, omits the psychic powers and instead has the jhānas. | This passage begins the six direct knowledges.
comment_text.mn12:9.1: After the first three of the direct knowledges, the sequence is interrupted with the insertion of these ten powers of a Realized One, also found at AN 10.21 and AN 10.22. The Vibhaṅga, an early Abhidhamma book, gives a detailed explanation (Vb 16:353 ff.). | Five powers are listed at AN 5.11 and six at AN 6.64.
comment_text.mn12:11.1: The Vibhaṅga explains this as knowing the circumstances that prevent or support the fruition of deeds, namely: place of rebirth (gati), form of reincarnation (upadhi, explained by the commentary as attabhāva), time (kāla), and effort (payoga). | See also the analysis of “deeds” (kamma) in MN 57, MN 135, and MN 136.
comment_text.mn12:14.1: This is not explained explicitly, but an example is found at DN 1:1.3.2, where the Buddha knows the difference between Brahmadatta, who had faith in the triple gem, and Suppiya who did not. Thus adhimutti (“conviction”) means “faith, belief” rather than “disposition”.
comment_text.mn12:15.1: Exemplified by the Buddha when he surveyed the world after his awakening to see the diverse spiritual potentials of beings (MN 26:21.2, MN 85:45.4, DN 14:3.6.2, SN 6.1:9.2, Kd 1:5.11.1).
comment_text.mn12:16.1: “Corruption” is any mental factor that darkens and diminishes meditation; “cleansing” is anything that brightens and enhances it. “Emergence” refers to understanding the reasons why one comes out of a given state of meditation (eg. MN 43:29.1). | The phrase “absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments” indicates that, although they are given various technical definitions, these are overlapping terms that describe in different ways the same field of deep meditation experiences.
comment_text.mn12:17.1: Here we return to the final three of the six direct knowledges, which also form the final three of the ten powers.
comment_text.mn12:21.4: This seems harsh, but the suttas see such denigration of the Buddha as deeply wicked, since it closes off the path to Nibbana, as at SN 42.9:4.12 where a village chief accuses the Buddha of destroying families by encouraging renunciation. At DN 24:1.16.13 the Buddha warns Sunakkhatta that the naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta, without likewise giving up his speech, thought, and view, will not even be able to enter the Buddha’s presence, much less debate him.
comment_text.mn12:22.1: These four “kinds of self-assurance” (vesārajja) are also found at AN 4.8. The first three are included in the Buddha’s dressing down of Sarabha at AN 3.64.
comment_text.mn12:23.1: In his first discourse, the Buddha says that he did not claim to be fully awakened until he had understand the four noble truths in all three rounds and twelve aspects (SN 56.11:10.1). | Here nimitta means “reason, ground, basis”.
comment_text.mn12:25.1: This was the accusation of Ariṭṭha (MN 22). The Chinese parallel identifies the “obstructions” as desire and lust.
comment_text.mn12:29.5: AN 8.69 and DN 16:3.21.3 both relate the Buddha entering these assemblies, but neither they, nor the Chinese parallel to this passage, attribute his confidence to the four kinds of self-assurance.
comment_text.mn12:29.6: Anekasataṁ khattiyaparisaṁ is singular, “an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats”, rather than “hundreds of assemblies of aristocrats”.
comment_text.mn12:32.1: These four, which are absent from the Chinese parallel, describe the births of different kinds of nāga (SN 29.1) and phoenix (SN 30.1).
comment_text.mn12:32.3: Compare the three “seeds” of Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.1: beings are born from an egg (āṇḍaja), from a living individual (jīvaja, i.e. “viviparous”), from a sprout (udbhijja, i.e. plants). Expanded to four at Aitareya Upaniṣad 3.3: from an egg, from a membrane (jāruja = jarāyuja, cf. Pali jalābuja), from moisture/sweat (svedaja, cf. Pali saṁsedaja), from a sprout. These are defined at Manusmṛti 1.43–6. The Jain Tattvārtha Sūtra 2.31–5 presents three kinds of birth: congealing (sammūrcchana), uterine (garbha; includes egg and womb), and spontaneous (upapāda, cf. Pali opapātika in the same sense). “Congealing” birth refers to all those not otherwise covered, and thus includes both “mosisture-born” and plants (cf. DN 15:21.2). | The Buddhist list is the only one that does not include plants, as Buddhists believe that consciousness does not take rebirth in plants. The Vedic position is that the soul (ātman) can be reborn in plants (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.2), while the Jains believed that all things living and not living possess souls (jīva).
comment_text.mn12:33.4: This is literally “membranous” reproduction, in reference to the membranes that envelop the fetus.
comment_text.mn12:35.3: The asuras (“titans”) are included with the gods in this classification; gods and titans are close enough to allow intermarriage (SN 11.13:11.1). The Chinese parallel, in common with later traditions, adds the titans as a separate realm here.
comment_text.mn12:37.1: Here the Buddha describes the process by which he knows where paths lead. First he comprehends their minds, then he infers their destiny, then he confirms the outcome. It is only in this limited way that he knows the future. If, as popular tradition would have it, he was literally omniscient, there would be no need to undertake such a laborious process involving inference, as he could simply directly see whatever he wanted.
comment_text.mn12:37.4: Such pits are frequently mentioned in the suttas and must have been a common sight. Since fired bricks were not regularly produced, perhaps they were used for metals or pottery, although kilns are also mentioned (AN 7.66:8.3, SN 12.51:12.1).
comment_text.mn12:38.3: Text omits ekanta (“exclusively”), as animals experience both pleasure and pain.
comment_text.mn12:39.3: The pain in the ghost realm is not sharp, severe, and exclusive like in hell, nor just sharp and severe as in the animal realm, but merely “mostly painful” (dukkhabahulā vedanā). The pain level is gradually diminishing, and with the human realm it flips, becoming mostly pleasant, then exclusively pleasant in the heaven realms.
comment_text.mn12:39.4: Perhaps the tree was in Australia, where the ground is stony, the leaf coverage scanty, and the flies ravenous.
comment_text.mn12:42.5: We have met tibba above in the sense of “sharp” feelings. At Mnd 14:58.13, such a forest is said to be one of the four kinds of darkness.
comment_text.mn12:44.1: The Buddha evidently introduces this topic because Sunakkhatta was impressed by displays of austerity. It is a unique description of the Bodhisatta’s practices before awakening. The practices, which for the most part sound very Jain-like, were undertaken in various periods during the six years after the Bodhisatta went forth and before his awakening. | The supposedly Jain “fourfold restraint” is recorded at MN 56:12.2 and DN 2:29.2, while at DN 25:16.4 the Buddha reinterprets it as keeping precepts.
comment_text.mn12:44.2: “Fervent mortifier” (tapassī), “rough-liver” (lūkha), “one living in disgust of sin” (jegucchī), “secluded” (pavivitta).
comment_text.mn12:45.1: Tapas (“ardor, fire. fervor, fervent mortification”) is the raging flame of righteous pain that courses through body when it is pushed to its extremes. This “fervor” burns off the corrupting traces of kamma and defilements. | Buddhist mendicants may not receive food in their hands, nor lick them while eating. Followers of the practices listed here would have walked steadily and randomly for alms, accepting only what was given at the time.
comment_text.mn12:45.2: Keeping sheep (eḷaka, for slaughter) goes against the Jain principle of non-violence, as does keeping weapons (daṇḍa). | A musala often means “pestle”, but it can also be a “shovel”; at MN 81:18.12 it is regarded as a virtue to not use one to dig the soil (which is regarded as being alive in Jainism). | Thusodaka is an alcoholic porridge fermented from grain-husks, mentioned alongside sovīraka in the Pali commentaries and Carakasaṁhitā 27g.191.
comment_text.mn12:45.6: It is not easy to meaningfully distinguish the various kinds of grain.
comment_text.mn12:45.7: All are extremely uncomfortable. Christian ascetics wore a “hair shirt” in order to “mortify the flesh” .
comment_text.mn12:45.8: Jain ascetics tear out their hair at ordination, rather than shaving.
comment_text.mn12:45.9: Remaining in one posture for months or years at a time is one of the most difficult practices.
comment_text.mn12:45.12: The “three times” are daybreak, noon, and dusk, considered the three crucial “junctures” (sandhyā). This seems out of place here. It was a Brahmanical practice (SN 7.21), as the Jains refused to bathe at all, hence the “rough living” of the following section. Indeed, bathing three times a day in the Indian climate would, for most of the year, be quite pleasant. Sometimes, however, it was deliberately done in the cold (Ud 1.9:1.3).
comment_text.mn12:46.1: “Rough” (lūkha) is related to the Sanskrit rūkṣa, among the meanings of which is “soiled, smeared, dirtied”.
comment_text.mn12:47.2: The Bodhisatta learned mindfulness while doing Jain-like practices and later incorporated it into the eightfold path (see also MN 36:20.7). He also learned mindfulness under Brahmanical teachers (MN 26:15.17). | “Pity” is dayā, which is similar to the more commonly found terms karuṇā or anukampa.
comment_text.mn12:47.3: To this day, Jain ascetics carry a soft broom to gently sweep away any insects in their path. | “Unclear ground” (visamagata) is explained by the commentary as ground that is uneven or covered in grass, branches, etc. A lion is said to reflect in the same way when setting out on a hunt (AN 10.21:1.7). | Compare Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.10.2, where a man carrying a palanquin is so scrupulous about avoiding treading on ants that he stops and starts, making the progress of the palanquin unsteady (viṣama-gatāṁ).
comment_text.mn12:48.1: “Seclusion” (viviktaśayyāsana) is classified by the Jains as an “external austerity” (bāhyatapas) at Tattvārthasūtra 9.19.
comment_text.mn12:48.10: This concludes the “spiritual path consisting of four factors” of MN 12:44.1.
comment_text.mn12:49.3: At Kd 6:14.6.3 the four “great unnaturals” (or “filthy edibles”, mahāvikaṭa) are said to be feces, urine, ash, and clay.
comment_text.mn12:50.4: Antaraṭṭhakā (Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit aṣṭaka-rātri) is the coldest part of Indian winter between the festival days that fall on the eighth day after the fullmoon in the two winter months of Māgha and Phagguna. This roughly corresponds with January, the coldest month in northern India.
comment_text.mn12:50.6: “Not supernaturally inspired” (anacchariyā) rejects the Vedic “channeling” of scripture from the Divinity, while “not learned before in the past” (pubbe assutapubbā), echoing the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:5.1), rejects the oral tradition.
comment_text.mn12:51.2: For “village louts” (gāmaṇḍalā), compare aṇḍaka in the sense “nasty, cruel” at MN 41:9.4.
comment_text.mn12:52.2: Compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2: “from purity of food there is purity of being; from purity of being there is stable memory (mindfulness); relying on memory there is release from all ties” (āhāraśuddhau sattvaśuddhiḥ; sattvaśuddhau dhruvā smṛtiḥ; smṛtilambhe sarvagranthīnāṁ vipramokṣaḥ).
comment_text.mn12:52.13: Āsītika is “eighty-year-old”, kāḷa is “time (of death)” (read kāla), pabba is “joint”.
comment_text.mn12:57.2: A view attributed to Makkhali Gosāla (DN 2:21.3). The idea is that transmigration is limited, so one will automatically be released after a certain number of lives.
comment_text.mn12:57.4: The gods there are all “non-returners” and will attain arahantship in that realm.
comment_text.mn12:58.2: This view and the next appear to be different ways of repeating the same view as before. Perhaps there is a subtle difference between them.
comment_text.mn12:60.2: This is, of course, the brahmins.
comment_text.mn12:61.2: Again, serving the sacred flame is a fundamental, perhaps the fundamental, rite of the brahmins.
comment_text.mn12:62.5: This situates this discourse, and hence the Sunakkhatta cycle as a whole, near the end of the Buddha’s life.
comment_text.mn12:62.6: Memory (sati), range (gati), retention (dhiti), and perfect lucidity of wisdom (paññāveyyattiya).
comment_text.mn12:64.1: We meet Nāgasamāla in less auspicious circumstances at Ud 8.7, where he stubbornly disagrees with the Buddha on which path to take.
comment_text.mn12:64.6: This original title is widely attested in the tradition, being found in some uddāna summary verses in Burmese and Sinhalese manuscripts, Mil 7.5.7:2.1, a Jātaka of the same name (Ja 94), several commentaries, and the Sanskrit and Chinese parallels. The subcommentary says that the name Mahāsīhanāda was given by the redactors.

root_text.mn12:2.2: So vesāliyaṁ parisati evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati:
root_text.mn12:2.4: Takkapariyāhataṁ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ deseti vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:2.5: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
root_text.mn12:3.1: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn12:3.2: Assosi kho āyasmā sāriputto sunakkhattassa licchaviputtassa vesāliyaṁ parisati evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsamānassa:
root_text.mn12:3.4: Takkapariyāhataṁ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ deseti vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:3.5: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
root_text.mn12:3.6: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto vesāliyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn12:3.8: So vesāliyaṁ parisati evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati:
root_text.mn12:3.10: Takkapariyāhataṁ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ deseti vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:3.11: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’”ti.
root_text.mn12:4.2: Kodhā ca panassa esā vācā bhāsitā.
root_text.mn12:4.3: ‘Avaṇṇaṁ bhāsissāmī’ti kho, sāriputta, sunakkhatto moghapuriso vaṇṇaṁyeva tathāgatassa bhāsati.
root_text.mn12:4.4: Vaṇṇo heso, sāriputta, tathāgatassa yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:4.5: ‘yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti.
root_text.mn12:5.1: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
root_text.mn12:5.2: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi, satthā devamanussānaṁ, buddho bhagavā’ti.
root_text.mn12:6.1: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
root_text.mn12:6.2: ‘itipi so bhagavā anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ, tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchati, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vattetī’ti.
root_text.mn12:7.1: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
root_text.mn12:7.2: ‘itipi so bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti—dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike cā’ti.
root_text.mn12:8.1: Ayampi hi nāma, sāriputta, sunakkhattassa moghapurisassa mayi dhammanvayo na bhavissati:
root_text.mn12:8.2: ‘itipi so bhagavā parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti—
root_text.mn12:8.3: sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.4: vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ vītarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.5: sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ sadosaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.6: vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ vītadosaṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.7: samohaṁ vā cittaṁ samohaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.8: vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ vītamohaṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.9: saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ saṅkhittaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.10: vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ vikkhittaṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.11: mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ mahaggataṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.12: amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ amahaggataṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.13: sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ sauttaraṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.14: anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ anuttaraṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.15: samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ samāhitaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.16: asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ asamāhitaṁ cittanti pajānāti;
root_text.mn12:8.17: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti,
root_text.mn12:8.18: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānātī’ti.
root_text.mn12:9.1: Dasa kho panimāni, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.
root_text.mn12:10.1: Idha, sāriputta, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn12:10.2: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.

root_text.mn12:11.2: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṁ kammasamādānānaṁ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.

root_text.mn12:12.2: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato sabbatthagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.

root_text.mn12:14.2: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato sattānaṁ nānādhimuttikataṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.

root_text.mn12:16.1: Puna caparaṁ, sāriputta, tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṁ saṅkilesaṁ vodānaṁ vuṭṭhānaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.

root_text.mn12:17.1: Puna caparaṁ, sāriputta, tathāgato anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. root_text.mn12:19.1: Puna caparaṁ, sāriputta, tathāgato āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn12:19.2: Yampi, sāriputta, tathāgato āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi, sāriputta, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.
root_text.mn12:20.1: Imāni kho, sāriputta, dasa tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.
root_text.mn12:21.1: Yo kho maṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ jānantaṁ evaṁ passantaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:21.3: takkapariyāhataṁ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ deseti vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānan’ti,
root_text.mn12:21.4: taṁ, sāriputta, vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:21.5: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṁ ārādheyya, evaṁ sampadamidaṁ, sāriputta, vadāmi.
root_text.mn12:21.6: Taṁ vācaṁ appahāya, taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:22.1: Cattārimāni, sāriputta, tathāgatassa vesārajjāni yehi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.
root_text.mn12:23.1: ‘Sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā’ti. Tatra vata maṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṁ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṁ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn12:23.2: Etamahaṁ, sāriputta, nimittaṁ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:24.1: ‘Khīṇāsavassa te paṭijānato ime āsavā aparikkhīṇā’ti. Tatra vata maṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṁ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṁ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn12:24.2: Etamahaṁ, sāriputta, nimittaṁ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:25.1: ‘Ye kho pana te antarāyikā dhammā vuttā, te paṭisevato nālaṁ antarāyāyā’ti. Tatra vata maṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṁ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṁ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn12:25.2: Etamahaṁ, sāriputta, nimittaṁ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:26.1: ‘Yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo desito, so na niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. Tatra vata maṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṁ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṁ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn12:26.2: Etamahaṁ, sāriputta, nimittaṁ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:27.1: Imāni kho, sāriputta, cattāri tathāgatassa vesārajjāni yehi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati, brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.

root_text.mn12:28.3: taṁ, sāriputta, vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:28.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṁ ārādheyya, evaṁ sampadamidaṁ, sāriputta, vadāmi.
root_text.mn12:28.5: Taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:29.3: Khattiyaparisā, brāhmaṇaparisā, gahapatiparisā, samaṇaparisā, cātumahārājikaparisā, tāvatiṁsaparisā, māraparisā, brahmaparisā—
root_text.mn12:29.5: Imehi kho, sāriputta, catūhi vesārajjehi samannāgato tathāgato imā aṭṭha parisā upasaṅkamati ajjhogāhati.
root_text.mn12:29.6: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, sāriputta, anekasataṁ khattiyaparisaṁ upasaṅkamitā.
root_text.mn12:29.7: Tatrapi mayā sannisinnapubbañceva, sallapitapubbañca, sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā.

root_text.mn12:36.1: Nirayañcāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, nirayagāmiñca maggaṁ, nirayagāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.2: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:36.3: Tiracchānayoniñcāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, tiracchānayonigāmiñca maggaṁ, tiracchānayonigāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.4: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṁ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:36.5: Pettivisayañcāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, pettivisayagāmiñca maggaṁ, pettivisayagāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.6: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:36.7: Manusse cāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, manussalokagāmiñca maggaṁ, manussalokagāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.8: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā manussesu upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:36.9: Deve cāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, devalokagāmiñca maggaṁ, devalokagāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.10: yathā paṭipanno ca kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:36.11: Nibbānañcāhaṁ, sāriputta, pajānāmi, nibbānagāmiñca maggaṁ, nibbānagāminiñca paṭipadaṁ;
root_text.mn12:36.12: yathā paṭipanno ca āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati tañca pajānāmi.
root_text.mn12:37.1: Idhāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:37.2: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:37.3: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:37.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, aṅgārakāsu sādhikaporisā pūrā aṅgārānaṁ vītaccikānaṁ vītadhūmānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:37.5: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva aṅgārakāsuṁ paṇidhāya.
root_text.mn12:37.6: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:37.7: ‘tathāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā imaṁyeva aṅgārakāsuṁ āgamissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:37.8: Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena tassā aṅgārakāsuyā patitaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:37.9: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:37.10: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:37.11: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.

root_text.mn12:38.9: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:38.10: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:38.11: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:39.1: Idha panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:39.2: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:39.3: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:39.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, rukkho visame bhūmibhāge jāto tanupattapalāso kabaracchāyo.
root_text.mn12:39.5: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva rukkhaṁ paṇidhāya.
root_text.mn12:39.6: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:39.7: ‘tathāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā imaṁyeva rukkhaṁ āgamissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:39.8: Tamenaṁ passeyya, aparena samayena tassa rukkhassa chāyāya nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:39.9: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:39.10: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:39.11: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:40.1: Idha panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:40.2: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā manussesu upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:40.3: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā manussesu upapannaṁ, sukhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:40.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, rukkho same bhūmibhāge jāto bahalapattapalāso sandacchāyo.
root_text.mn12:40.5: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva rukkhaṁ paṇidhāya.
root_text.mn12:40.6: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:40.7: ‘tathāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā imameva rukkhaṁ āgamissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:40.8: Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena tassa rukkhassa chāyāya nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā sukhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:40.9: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:40.10: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā manussesu upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:40.11: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā manussesu upapannaṁ, sukhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:41.1: Idha panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
root_text.mn12:41.2: ‘tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:41.3: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:41.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, pāsādo, tatrāssa kūṭāgāraṁ ullittāvalittaṁ nivātaṁ phusitaggaḷaṁ pihitavātapānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:41.5: Tatrāssa pallaṅko gonakatthato paṭikatthato paṭalikatthato kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇo sauttaracchado ubhatolohitakūpadhāno.
root_text.mn12:41.6: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva pāsādaṁ paṇidhāya.
root_text.mn12:41.7: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:41.8: ‘tathāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā imaṁyeva pāsādaṁ āgamissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:41.9: Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena tasmiṁ pāsāde tasmiṁ kūṭāgāre tasmiṁ pallaṅke nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:41.10: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:41.11: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho yathā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissatīti.
root_text.mn12:41.12: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:42.1: Idha panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaccaṁ puggalaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
root_text.mn12:42.2: tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatīti.
root_text.mn12:42.3: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantaṁ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:42.4: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, pokkharaṇī acchodakā sātodakā sītodakā setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā.
root_text.mn12:42.6: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito ekāyanena maggena tameva pokkharaṇiṁ paṇidhāya.
root_text.mn12:42.7: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:42.8: ‘tathā bhavaṁ puriso paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā imaṁyeva pokkharaṇiṁ āgamissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:42.9: Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena taṁ pokkharaṇiṁ ogāhetvā nhāyitvā ca pivitvā ca sabbadarathakilamathapariḷāhaṁ paṭippassambhetvā paccuttaritvā tasmiṁ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:42.10: Evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, idhekaccaṁ puggalaṁ evaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
root_text.mn12:42.11: ‘tathāyaṁ puggalo paṭipanno tathā ca iriyati tañca maggaṁ samārūḷho, yathā āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:42.12: Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantaṁ, ekantasukhā vedanā vedayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:43.1: Yo kho maṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ jānantaṁ evaṁ passantaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:43.3: takkapariyāhataṁ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ deseti vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānan’ti
root_text.mn12:43.4: taṁ, sāriputta, vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:43.5: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṁ ārādheyya; evaṁ sampadamidaṁ, sāriputta, vadāmi
root_text.mn12:43.6: taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṁ nikkhitto evaṁ niraye.
root_text.mn12:44.1: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, sāriputta, caturaṅgasamannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ caritā—
root_text.mn12:44.2: tapassī sudaṁ homi paramatapassī, lūkho sudaṁ homi paramalūkho, jegucchī sudaṁ homi paramajegucchī, pavivitto sudaṁ homi paramapavivitto.
root_text.mn12:45.1: Tatrāssu me idaṁ, sāriputta, tapassitāya hoti—acelako homi muttācāro hatthāpalekhano, naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko; nābhihaṭaṁ na uddissakataṁ na nimantanaṁ sādiyāmi.
root_text.mn12:45.2: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāmi, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāmi, na eḷakamantaraṁ, na daṇḍamantaraṁ, na musalamantaraṁ, na dvinnaṁ bhuñjamānānaṁ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī; na macchaṁ na maṁsaṁ na suraṁ na merayaṁ na thusodakaṁ pivāmi;
root_text.mn12:45.3: so ekāgāriko vā homi ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā homi dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā homi sattālopiko;
root_text.mn12:45.4: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpemi, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpemi …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpemi;
root_text.mn12:45.5: ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāremi, dvīhikampi āhāraṁ āhāremi …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāremi; iti evarūpaṁ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:45.6: So sākabhakkho vā homi, sāmākabhakkho vā homi, nīvārabhakkho vā homi, daddulabhakkho vā homi, haṭabhakkho vā homi, kaṇabhakkho vā homi, ācāmabhakkho vā homi, piññākabhakkho vā homi, tiṇabhakkho vā homi, gomayabhakkho vā homi, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpemi pavattaphalabhojī.
root_text.mn12:45.7: So sāṇānipi dhāremi, masāṇānipi dhāremi, chavadussānipi dhāremi, paṁsukūlānipi dhāremi, tirīṭānipi dhāremi, ajinampi dhāremi, ajinakkhipampi dhāremi, kusacīrampi dhāremi, vākacīrampi dhāremi, phalakacīrampi dhāremi, kesakambalampi dhāremi, vāḷakambalampi dhāremi, ulūkapakkhampi dhāremi;
root_text.mn12:45.13: iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:46.1: Tatrāssu me idaṁ, sāriputta, lūkhasmiṁ hoti—
root_text.mn12:46.2: nekavassagaṇikaṁ rajojallaṁ kāye sannicitaṁ hoti papaṭikajātaṁ.
root_text.mn12:46.3: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, tindukakhāṇu nekavassagaṇiko sannicito hoti papaṭikajāto, evamevāssu me, sāriputta, nekavassagaṇikaṁ rajojallaṁ kāye sannicitaṁ hoti papaṭikajātaṁ.
root_text.mn12:46.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, sāriputta, na evaṁ hoti:
root_text.mn12:46.5: ‘aho vatāhaṁ imaṁ rajojallaṁ pāṇinā parimajjeyyaṁ, aññe vā pana me imaṁ rajojallaṁ pāṇinā parimajjeyyun’ti.
root_text.mn12:47.1: Tatrāssu me idaṁ, sāriputta, jegucchismiṁ hoti—
root_text.mn12:47.2: so kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, satova abhikkamāmi, satova paṭikkamāmi, yāva udakabindumhipi me dayā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti:
root_text.mn12:48.1: Tatrāssu me idaṁ, sāriputta, pavivittasmiṁ hoti—
root_text.mn12:48.2: so kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, aññataraṁ araññāyatanaṁ ajjhogāhetvā viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:48.3: Yadā passāmi gopālakaṁ vā pasupālakaṁ vā tiṇahārakaṁ vā kaṭṭhahārakaṁ vā vanakammikaṁ vā, vanena vanaṁ gahanena gahanaṁ ninnena ninnaṁ thalena thalaṁ sampatāmi.
root_text.mn12:48.5: Mā maṁ te addasaṁsu ahañca mā te addasanti.
root_text.mn12:48.6: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, āraññako mago manusse disvā vanena vanaṁ gahanena gahanaṁ ninnena ninnaṁ thalena thalaṁ sampatati;
root_text.mn12:48.7: evameva kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, yadā passāmi gopālakaṁ vā pasupālakaṁ vā tiṇahārakaṁ vā kaṭṭhahārakaṁ vā vanakammikaṁ vā vanena vanaṁ gahanena gahanaṁ ninnena ninnaṁ thalena thalaṁ sampatāmi.
root_text.mn12:48.9: Mā maṁ te addasaṁsu ahañca mā te addasanti.
root_text.mn12:49.1: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, ye te goṭṭhā paṭṭhitagāvo apagatagopālakā, tattha catukkuṇḍiko upasaṅkamitvā yāni tāni vacchakānaṁ taruṇakānaṁ dhenupakānaṁ gomayāni tāni sudaṁ āhāremi.
root_text.mn12:49.2: Yāvakīvañca me, sāriputta, sakaṁ muttakarīsaṁ apariyādinnaṁ hoti, sakaṁyeva sudaṁ muttakarīsaṁ āhāremi.
root_text.mn12:50.1: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, aññataraṁ bhiṁsanakaṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ ajjhogāhetvā viharāmi.
root_text.mn12:50.2: Tatrāssudaṁ, sāriputta, bhiṁsanakassa vanasaṇḍassa bhiṁsanakatasmiṁ hoti—
root_text.mn12:50.3: yo koci avītarāgo taṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ pavisati, yebhuyyena lomāni haṁsanti.
root_text.mn12:50.4: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, yā tā rattiyo sītā hemantikā antaraṭṭhakā himapātasamayā tathārūpāsu rattīsu rattiṁ abbhokāse viharāmi, divā vanasaṇḍe;
root_text.mn12:50.5: gimhānaṁ pacchime māse divā abbhokāse viharāmi, rattiṁ vanasaṇḍe.
root_text.mn12:50.6: Apissu maṁ, sāriputta, ayaṁ anacchariyagāthā paṭibhāsi pubbe assutapubbā:
root_text.mn12:51.1: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, susāne seyyaṁ kappemi chavaṭṭhikāni upadhāya.
root_text.mn12:51.2: Apissu maṁ, sāriputta, gāmaṇḍalā upasaṅkamitvā oṭṭhubhantipi, omuttentipi, paṁsukenapi okiranti, kaṇṇasotesupi salākaṁ pavesenti.
root_text.mn12:51.3: Na kho panāhaṁ, sāriputta, abhijānāmi tesu pāpakaṁ cittaṁ uppādetā.
root_text.mn12:52.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:52.5: Te kolampi khādanti, kolacuṇṇampi khādanti, kolodakampi pivanti—
root_text.mn12:52.7: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaṁyeva kolaṁ āhāraṁ āhāritā.
root_text.mn12:52.8: Siyā kho pana te, sāriputta, evamassa:
root_text.mn12:52.10: Na kho panetaṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn12:52.11: Tadāpi etaparamoyeva kolo ahosi seyyathāpi etarahi.
root_text.mn12:52.12: Tassa mayhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaṁyeva kolaṁ āhāraṁ āhārayato adhimattakasimānaṁ patto kāyo hoti.
root_text.mn12:52.13: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.14: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṁ; evamevassu me ānisadaṁ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.15: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako unnatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.16: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.17: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.18: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.19: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, ‘udaracchaviṁ parimasissāmī’ti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, ‘piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ parimasissāmī’ti udaracchaviṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, yāvassu me, sāriputta, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.20: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, ‘vaccaṁ vā muttaṁ vā karissāmī’ti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:52.21: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, tameva kāyaṁ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anomajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṁ, sāriputta, pāṇinā gattāni anomajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā patanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:53-55.7: Te taṇḍulampi khādanti, taṇḍulacuṇṇampi khādanti, taṇḍulodakampi pivanti—
root_text.mn12:53-55.9: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaṁyeva taṇḍulaṁ āhāraṁ āhāritā.
root_text.mn12:53-55.10: Siyā kho pana te, sāriputta, evamassa:
root_text.mn12:53-55.12: Na kho panetaṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn12:53-55.13: Tadāpi etaparamoyeva taṇḍulo ahosi, seyyathāpi etarahi.
root_text.mn12:53-55.14: Tassa mayhaṁ, sāriputta, ekaṁyeva taṇḍulaṁ āhāraṁ āhārayato adhimattakasimānaṁ patto kāyo hoti.
root_text.mn12:53-55.15: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.16: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṁ; evamevassu me ānisadaṁ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.17: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako unnatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.18: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.19: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.20: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.21: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, ‘udaracchaviṁ parimasissāmī’ti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, ‘piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ parimasissāmī’ti udaracchaviṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi. Yāvassu me, sāriputta, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.22: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, ‘vaccaṁ vā muttaṁ vā karissāmī’ti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:53-55.23: So kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, tameva kāyaṁ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anomajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṁ, sāriputta, pāṇinā gattāni anomajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā patanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn12:56.1: Tāyapi kho ahaṁ, sāriputta, iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkarakārikāya nājjhagamaṁ uttariṁ manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ.
root_text.mn12:56.3: Imissāyeva ariyāya paññāya anadhigamā, yāyaṁ ariyā paññā adhigatā ariyā niyyānikā, niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
root_text.mn12:57.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:57.3: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, saṁsāro sulabharūpo yo mayā asaṁsaritapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
root_text.mn12:57.4: Suddhāvāse cāhaṁ, sāriputta, deve saṁsareyyaṁ, nayimaṁ lokaṁ punarāgaccheyyaṁ.
root_text.mn12:58.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:58.3: Na kho pana sā, sāriputta, upapatti sulabharūpā yā mayā anupapannapubbā iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
root_text.mn12:58.4: Suddhāvāse cāhaṁ, sāriputta, deve upapajjeyyaṁ, nayimaṁ lokaṁ punarāgaccheyyaṁ.
root_text.mn12:59.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:59.3: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, āvāso sulabharūpo yo mayā anāvuṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
root_text.mn12:59.4: Suddhāvāse cāhaṁ, sāriputta, deve āvaseyyaṁ, nayimaṁ lokaṁ punarāgaccheyyaṁ.
root_text.mn12:60.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:60.3: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, yañño sulabharūpo yo mayā ayiṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, tañca kho raññā vā satā khattiyena muddhāvasittena brāhmaṇena vā mahāsālena.
root_text.mn12:61.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:61.3: Na kho pana so, sāriputta, aggi sulabharūpo yo mayā apariciṇṇapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā, tañca kho raññā vā satā khattiyena muddhāvasittena brāhmaṇena vā mahāsālena.
root_text.mn12:62.1: Santi kho pana, sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn12:62.2: ‘yāvadevāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso daharo hoti yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā tāvadeva paramena paññāveyyattiyena samannāgato hoti.
root_text.mn12:62.3: Yato ca kho ayaṁ bhavaṁ puriso jiṇṇo hoti vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, āsītiko vā nāvutiko vā vassasatiko vā jātiyā, atha tamhā paññāveyyattiyā, parihāyatī’ti.
root_text.mn12:62.4: Na kho panetaṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn12:62.5: Ahaṁ kho pana, sāriputta, etarahi jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, āsītiko me vayo vattati.
root_text.mn12:62.6: Idha me assu, sāriputta, cattāro sāvakā vassasatāyukā vassasatajīvino, paramāya satiyā ca gatiyā ca dhitiyā ca samannāgatā paramena ca paññāveyyattiyena.
root_text.mn12:62.7: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho sikkhito katahattho katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasireneva tiriyaṁ tālacchāyaṁ atipāteyya,
root_text.mn12:62.8: evaṁ adhimattasatimanto evaṁ adhimattagatimanto evaṁ adhimattadhitimanto evaṁ paramena paññāveyyattiyena samannāgatā.
root_text.mn12:62.9: Te maṁ catunnaṁ satipaṭṭhānānaṁ upādāyupādāya pañhaṁ puccheyyuṁ, puṭṭho puṭṭho cāhaṁ tesaṁ byākareyyaṁ, byākatañca me byākatato dhāreyyuṁ, na ca maṁ dutiyakaṁ uttari paṭipuccheyyuṁ.
root_text.mn12:62.10: Aññatra asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā, aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā apariyādinnāyevassa, sāriputta, tathāgatassa dhammadesanā, apariyādinnaṁyevassa tathāgatassa dhammapadabyañjanaṁ, apariyādinnaṁyevassa tathāgatassa pañhapaṭibhānaṁ.
root_text.mn12:62.11: Atha me te cattāro sāvakā vassasatāyukā vassasatajīvino vassasatassa accayena kālaṁ kareyyuṁ.
root_text.mn12:62.12: Mañcakena cepi maṁ, sāriputta, pariharissatha, nevatthi tathāgatassa paññāveyyattiyassa aññathattaṁ.
root_text.mn12:63.1: Yaṁ kho taṁ, sāriputta, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
root_text.mn12:63.2: ‘asammohadhammo satto loke uppanno bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti, mameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya
root_text.mn12:63.3: ‘asammohadhammo satto loke uppanno bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’”ti.
root_text.mn12:64.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṁ bījayamāno.
root_text.mn12:64.2: Atha kho āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn12:64.4: Api hi me, bhante, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ sutvā lomāni haṭṭhāni.
root_text.mn12:64.6: “Tasmātiha tvaṁ, nāgasamāla, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ lomahaṁsanapariyāyotveva naṁ dhārehī”ti.
root_text.mn12:64.8: Attamano āyasmā nāgasamālo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn12:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
translation_text.mn12:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying outside the city of Vesālī in a woodland grove west of the town.
translation_text.mn12:2.1: Now at that time Sunakkhatta the Licchavi had recently left this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn12:2.2: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī:
translation_text.mn12:2.3: “The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn12:2.4: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.
translation_text.mn12:2.5: And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.”
translation_text.mn12:3.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
translation_text.mn12:3.2: He heard what Sunakkhatta was saying.
translation_text.mn12:3.6: Then he wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn12:4.1: “Sāriputta, Sunakkhatta, that futile man, is angry.
translation_text.mn12:4.2: His words are spoken out of anger.
translation_text.mn12:4.3: Thinking he criticizes the Realized One, in fact he just praises him.
translation_text.mn12:4.4: For it is praise of the Realized One to say:
translation_text.mn12:4.5: ‘His teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.’
translation_text.mn12:5.1: But there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
translation_text.mn12:5.2: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn12:6.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
translation_text.mn12:6.2: ‘That Blessed One wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.’
translation_text.mn12:7.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
translation_text.mn12:7.2: ‘That Blessed One, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, hears both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.’
translation_text.mn12:8.1: And there’s no way Sunakkhatta will infer about me from the teaching:
translation_text.mn12:8.2: ‘That Blessed One understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with his own mind.
translation_text.mn12:8.3: He understands mind with greed as “mind with greed,”
translation_text.mn12:8.4: and mind without greed as “mind without greed.”
translation_text.mn12:9.1: There are these ten powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:10.1: Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible, and the impossible as impossible.
translation_text.mn12:10.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:11.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.
translation_text.mn12:11.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:12.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands where all paths of practice lead.
translation_text.mn12:12.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:13.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the world with its many and diverse elements.
translation_text.mn12:13.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:14.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the diverse convictions of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn12:14.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:15.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after encompassing them with his mind.
translation_text.mn12:15.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:16.1: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.
translation_text.mn12:16.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:17.1: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn12:17.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:18.1: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn12:18.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
translation_text.mn12:19.1: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn12:19.2: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:20.1: A Realized One possesses these ten powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:21.1: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn12:21.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn12:21.3: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’
translation_text.mn12:21.4: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:21.5: Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say.
translation_text.mn12:21.6: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:22.1: Sāriputta, a Realized One has four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:23.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to be a fully awakened Buddha, but you don’t understand these things.’
translation_text.mn12:23.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:24.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘You claim to have ended all defilements, but you still have these defilements.’
translation_text.mn12:24.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:25.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The acts that you say are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.’
translation_text.mn12:25.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:26.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The teaching doesn’t lead those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it is taught.’
translation_text.mn12:26.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:27.1: A Realized One possesses these four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
translation_text.mn12:28.1: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn12:28.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’
translation_text.mn12:28.3: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:29.1: Sāriputta, there are these eight assemblies.
translation_text.mn12:29.3: The assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.
translation_text.mn12:29.5: Possessing these four kinds of self-assurance, the Realized One approaches and enters right into these eight assemblies.
translation_text.mn12:29.6: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats.
translation_text.mn12:29.7: There I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.
translation_text.mn12:29.8: But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure.
translation_text.mn12:29.9: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:30.1: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of brahmins …
translation_text.mn12:30.4: the gods of the four great kings …
translation_text.mn12:30.8: There too I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.
translation_text.mn12:30.9: But I don’t see any reason to feel afraid or insecure.
translation_text.mn12:30.10: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
translation_text.mn12:31.1: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn12:31.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’
translation_text.mn12:31.3: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:32.1: Sāriputta, there are these four kinds of reproduction.
translation_text.mn12:32.3: Reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.
translation_text.mn12:33.1: And what is reproduction from an egg?
translation_text.mn12:33.2: There are beings who are born by breaking out of an eggshell.
translation_text.mn12:33.3: This is called reproduction from an egg.
translation_text.mn12:33.4: And what is reproduction from a womb?
translation_text.mn12:33.5: There are beings who are born by breaking out of the amniotic sac.
translation_text.mn12:33.6: This is called reproduction from a womb.
translation_text.mn12:33.7: And what is reproduction from moisture?
translation_text.mn12:33.8: There are beings who are born in a rotten fish, in a rotten carcass, in rotten dough, in a cesspool or a sump.
translation_text.mn12:33.9: This is called reproduction from moisture.
translation_text.mn12:33.11: Gods, hell-beings, certain humans, and certain beings in the lower realms.
translation_text.mn12:33.13: These are the four kinds of reproduction.
translation_text.mn12:34.1: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn12:34.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones …’
translation_text.mn12:34.3: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:35.3: Hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, humanity, and the gods.
translation_text.mn12:36.1: I understand hell, and the path and practice that leads to hell.
translation_text.mn12:36.2: And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn12:36.9: gods, and the path and practice that leads to the world of the gods.
translation_text.mn12:36.10: And I understand how someone practicing that way, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn12:36.11: And I understand extinguishment, and the path and practice that leads to extinguishment.
translation_text.mn12:36.12: And I understand how someone practicing that way realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn12:37.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:37.2: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
translation_text.mn12:37.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in hell, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn12:37.4: Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
translation_text.mn12:37.5: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same pit of coals.
translation_text.mn12:37.6: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:37.7: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very pit of coals.’
translation_text.mn12:37.8: Some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that pit of coals, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. …
translation_text.mn12:38.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:38.2: ‘This individual … will be reborn in the animal realm.’
translation_text.mn12:38.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the animal realm, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn12:38.4: Suppose there was a sewer deeper than a man’s height, full to the brim with feces.
translation_text.mn12:38.5: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same sewer.
translation_text.mn12:38.6: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:38.7: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very sewer.’
translation_text.mn12:38.8: Some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that sewer, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. …
translation_text.mn12:39.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:39.2: ‘This individual … will be reborn in the ghost realm.’
translation_text.mn12:39.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the ghost realm, where they experience mostly painful feelings.
translation_text.mn12:39.4: Suppose there was a tree growing on rugged ground, with thin foliage casting dappled shade.
translation_text.mn12:39.5: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same tree.
translation_text.mn12:39.6: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:39.7: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’
translation_text.mn12:39.8: Some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience mostly painful feelings. …
translation_text.mn12:40.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:40.2: ‘This individual … will be reborn among human beings.’
translation_text.mn12:40.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn among human beings, where they experience mostly pleasant feelings.
translation_text.mn12:40.4: Suppose there was a tree growing on smooth ground, with abundant foliage casting dense shade.
translation_text.mn12:40.5: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same tree.
translation_text.mn12:40.6: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:40.7: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very tree.’
translation_text.mn12:40.8: Some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience mostly pleasant feelings. …
translation_text.mn12:41.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:41.2: ‘This individual … will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’
translation_text.mn12:41.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in a heavenly realm, where they experience feelings of perfect happiness.
translation_text.mn12:41.4: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse with a peaked roof, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with door fastened and window shuttered.
translation_text.mn12:41.5: And it had a couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.
translation_text.mn12:41.6: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same stilt longhouse.
translation_text.mn12:41.7: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:41.8: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very stilt longhouse.’
translation_text.mn12:41.9: Some time later they see them sitting or lying in that stilt longhouse, where they experience feelings of perfect happiness. …
translation_text.mn12:42.1: When I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:42.2: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.mn12:42.3: Some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing feelings of perfect happiness.
translation_text.mn12:42.4: Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.
translation_text.mn12:42.5: Nearby was a dense forest grove.
translation_text.mn12:42.6: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched. And they have set out on a path that meets with that same lotus pond.
translation_text.mn12:42.7: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:
translation_text.mn12:42.8: ‘This person is proceeding in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will arrive at that very lotus pond.’
translation_text.mn12:42.9: Some time later they would see that person after they had plunged into that lotus pond, bathed and drunk. When all their stress, weariness, and heat exhaustion had faded away, they emerged and sat or lay down in that woodland thicket, where they experienced feelings of perfect happiness.
translation_text.mn12:42.10: In the same way, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual, I understand:
translation_text.mn12:42.11: ‘This individual is practicing in such a way and is riding upon such a path that they will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.mn12:42.12: Some time later I see that they have indeed realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements, experiencing feelings of perfect happiness.
translation_text.mn12:43.1: When I know and see in this way, suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn12:43.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama has no superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn12:43.3: He teaches what he’s worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing his own perspective.’
translation_text.mn12:43.4: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:43.5: Just as a mendicant accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom would reach enlightenment in this very life, such is the consequence, I say.
translation_text.mn12:43.6: Unless they give up that speech and that thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
translation_text.mn12:44.1: Sāriputta, I recall having practiced a spiritual path consisting of four factors.
translation_text.mn12:44.2: I used to be a fervent mortifier, the ultimate fervent mortifier. I used to live rough, the ultimate rough-liver. I used to live in disgust of sin, the ultimate one living in disgust of sin. I used to be secluded, in ultimate seclusion.
translation_text.mn12:45.1: And this is what my fervent mortification was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and didn’t come or stop when asked. I didn’t consent to food brought to me, or food prepared specially for me, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.mn12:45.2: I didn’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. I accepted no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drank no fermented gruel.
translation_text.mn12:45.3: I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.mn12:45.4: I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.mn12:45.5: I ate once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.mn12:45.6: I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.mn12:45.7: I wore robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.mn12:45.8: I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.mn12:45.9: I constantly stood, turning down seats.
translation_text.mn12:45.10: I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.mn12:45.11: I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed.
translation_text.mn12:45.12: I was devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
translation_text.mn12:45.13: And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
translation_text.mn12:45.14: Such was my practice of fervent mortification.
translation_text.mn12:46.1: And this is what my rough living was like.
translation_text.mn12:46.2: The dust and dirt built up on my body over many years until it started flaking off.
translation_text.mn12:46.3: It’s like the trunk of a pale-moon ebony tree, which builds up bark over many years until it starts flaking off.
translation_text.mn12:46.4: But it didn’t occur to me:
translation_text.mn12:46.5: ‘Oh, this dust and dirt must be rubbed off by my hand or another’s.’
translation_text.mn12:47.1: And this is what my living in disgust of sin was like.
translation_text.mn12:47.2: I’d step forward or back ever so mindfully, so I was full of pity regarding even a drop of water, thinking:
translation_text.mn12:47.3: ‘May I not injure any little creatures on unclear ground.’
translation_text.mn12:47.4: Such was my living in disgust of sin.
translation_text.mn12:48.1: And this is what my seclusion was like.
translation_text.mn12:48.2: I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there.
translation_text.mn12:48.3: When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I’d flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands.
translation_text.mn12:48.5: So that I wouldn’t see them, nor they me.
translation_text.mn12:48.6: I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.
translation_text.mn12:48.10: Such was my practice of seclusion.
translation_text.mn12:49.1: I would go on all fours into the cow-pens after the cattle had left and eat the dung of the young suckling calves.
translation_text.mn12:49.2: As long as my own urine and excrement lasted, I would even eat that.
translation_text.mn12:49.3: Such was my eating of most unnatural things.
translation_text.mn12:50.1: I would plunge deep into an awe-inspiring forest grove and stay there.

translation_text.mn12:50.4: And on days such as the cold spell when the snow falls in the January winter, I stayed in the open by night and in the forest by day.
translation_text.mn12:50.5: But in the last month of summer I’d stay in the open by day and in the forest by night.
translation_text.mn12:50.6: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:

translation_text.mn12:51.1: I would make my bed in a charnel ground, with the bones of the dead for a pillow.
translation_text.mn12:51.2: Then village louts would come up to me. They’d spit and piss on me, throw mud on me, even poke sticks in my ears.
translation_text.mn12:51.3: But I don’t recall ever having a bad thought about them.
translation_text.mn12:51.4: Such was my abiding in equanimity.

translation_text.mn12:52.5: So they eat jujubes and jujube powder, and drink jujube juice.
translation_text.mn12:52.6: And they enjoy many jujube concoctions.
translation_text.mn12:52.7: I recall eating just a single jujube.
translation_text.mn12:52.9: at that time the jujubes must have been very big.
translation_text.mn12:52.10: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.mn12:52.11: The jujubes then were at most the same size as today.
translation_text.mn12:52.12: Eating so very little, my body became severely emaciated.
translation_text.mn12:52.13: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
translation_text.mn12:52.14: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
translation_text.mn12:52.15: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
translation_text.mn12:52.16: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
translation_text.mn12:52.17: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
translation_text.mn12:52.18: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
translation_text.mn12:52.19: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
translation_text.mn12:52.20: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
translation_text.mn12:52.21: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

translation_text.mn12:56.1: But Sāriputta, I did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work.
translation_text.mn12:56.3: Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
